investmentAmount.label: Investment Amount (USD)
investmentAmount.tooltip: The initial amount of money you want to invest at the start of this backtest. This is the starting capital that will be used across all selected strategies. You can also add periodic funding (daily/weekly/monthly) in addition to this initial amount.

advancedPortfolio.title: Advanced Portfolio Setup
advancedPortfolio.description: Set up your initial portfolio with specific assets and USDC amounts. This allows you to simulate starting with an existing portfolio or a custom allocation.
advancedPortfolio.currentPortfolioTooltip: Your current portfolio configuration. Click Edit to modify or Reset to Simple to use investment amount instead.

assets.label: Assets
assets.helper: Add assets to your initial portfolio. For now, only BTC is supported, but more assets will be available in the future.

usdcAmount.label: USDC Amount
usdcAmount.helper: Starting USDC (stablecoin) amount in your portfolio.

fundingSchedule.label: Periodic Funding
fundingSchedule.helper: Add funds to your portfolio on a regular schedule (daily, weekly, or monthly). Set amount to 0 to disable.
fundingSchedule.tooltip: Periodic funding allows you to simulate adding money to your portfolio over time, similar to dollar-cost averaging with additional capital.

dateRange.label: Date Range
dateRange.helper: What time period do you want to test?
dateRange.tooltip: The time period for testing your strategies. Select a date range to see how strategies would have performed during that specific period. Longer periods provide more reliable results.

timeframe.label: Candlestick Timeframe
timeframe.helper: Select the timeframe for market data (1h = hourly, 4h = 4-hour, 1d = daily, 1w = weekly, 1m = monthly)
timeframe.tooltip: The granularity of market data used for calculations. Hourly (1h) provides the most detail but requires more data. Daily (1d) is recommended for most strategies as it balances detail with performance.

strategySelection.helper: Select strategies to compare (choose 2 or more)
strategySelection.tooltip: Choose which investment strategies you want to compare. Select at least 2 strategies to see how they perform side-by-side. Each strategy uses different rules for when and how much to invest.

mode.helper: Choose how you want to compare strategies
mode.tooltip: Compare Strategies: Compare different strategy types (e.g., DCA vs Lump Sum). Compare Variants: Compare the same strategy with different parameter settings (e.g., DCA weekly vs DCA daily).

variantMode.label: Parameter Variants
variantMode.selectStrategyPlaceholder: Choose a strategy to create variants
variantMode.noVariants: No variants added yet. Click 'Add Variant' to create one.
variantMode.variantNameHelp: Enter a custom name for this parameter configuration (e.g., 'Aggressive RSI', 'Conservative DCA')

strategyDescriptions.lump-sum: Invest the entire amount at the start date and hold. Simple buy-and-hold strategy.
strategyDescriptions.dca: Invest a fixed amount at regular intervals (daily, weekly, or monthly), regardless of price. Reduces the impact of volatility.
strategyDescriptions.rsi-dca: Weekly DCA with increased purchases when RSI indicates oversold conditions. Skips buying when overbought.
strategyDescriptions.dip-buyer-dca: Weekly DCA with increased purchases when price drops significantly from recent highs. Buy the dip strategy.
strategyDescriptions.moving-average-dca: Weekly DCA with increased purchases when price is below the moving average. Trend-following strategy.
strategyDescriptions.combined-smart-dca: Combines RSI, Moving Average, and Dip Buyer signals to adjust weekly DCA purchases. Most sophisticated strategy.
strategyDescriptions.rebalancing: Maintains a target asset allocation (e.g., 80% BTC / 20% USDC) by automatically buying or selling when the allocation drifts beyond configurable thresholds. Automatically rebalances to keep your portfolio at the target allocation.

parameterModal.title: Customize Parameters - {strategy}
parameterModal.noParameters: No customizable parameters for this strategy

dca.frequencyTooltip: How often the strategy will make purchases. Daily means every day, weekly means once per week, monthly means once per month. More frequent purchases can reduce the impact of price volatility.

rsi.rsiPeriodTooltip: The number of periods (days) used to calculate the RSI indicator. A shorter period (e.g., 7) reacts faster to price changes, while a longer period (e.g., 21) is smoother and less sensitive.
rsi.oversoldThresholdHelp: RSI value below which to buy more (default: 30)
rsi.oversoldThresholdTooltip: When RSI falls below this value, the strategy considers the asset oversold (potentially undervalued) and increases the purchase amount. Lower values (e.g., 20) mean more conservative buying, higher values (e.g., 40) mean more aggressive buying.
rsi.overboughtThresholdHelp: RSI value above which to skip buying (default: 70)
rsi.overboughtThresholdTooltip: When RSI rises above this value, the strategy considers the asset overbought (potentially overvalued) and skips the purchase. Higher values (e.g., 80) mean fewer skipped purchases, lower values (e.g., 60) mean more skipped purchases.
rsi.buyMultiplierHelp: Multiplier for purchase amount when oversold (default: 2.0x)
rsi.buyMultiplierTooltip: When RSI indicates oversold conditions, the strategy multiplies the normal purchase amount by this value. For example, 2.0x means buying twice the normal amount. Higher multipliers mean buying more aggressively when prices drop.

dip.lookbackDaysHelp: Number of days to look back for recent high (default: 30)
dip.lookbackDaysTooltip: The number of days to look back to find the recent high price. A shorter period (e.g., 14 days) detects smaller dips, while a longer period (e.g., 60 days) only detects larger dips from longer-term highs.
dip.dropThresholdHelp: Percentage drop from recent high to trigger buy (default: 10%)
dip.dropThresholdTooltip: The percentage drop from the recent high price that triggers increased buying. For example, 10% means if the price drops 10% from the recent high, the strategy will buy more. Lower values (e.g., 5%) trigger more often, higher values (e.g., 20%) trigger less often.
dip.buyMultiplierHelp: Multiplier for purchase amount when dip detected (default: 2.0x)
dip.buyMultiplierTooltip: When a dip is detected, the strategy multiplies the normal purchase amount by this value. For example, 2.0x means buying twice the normal amount during dips. Higher multipliers mean buying more aggressively when prices drop significantly.

ma.maPeriodTooltip: The number of days used to calculate the moving average. A shorter period (e.g., 20 days) reacts faster to price changes, while a longer period (e.g., 200 days) represents a longer-term trend. When price is below the moving average, it may indicate a buying opportunity.
ma.buyMultiplierHelp: Multiplier for purchase amount when price below MA (default: 2.0x)
ma.buyMultiplierTooltip: When the current price is below the moving average, the strategy multiplies the normal purchase amount by this value. For example, 2.0x means buying twice the normal amount. This follows the trend-following principle of buying more when price is below the average.

combined.rsiPeriodTooltip: The number of periods (days) used to calculate the RSI indicator. A shorter period reacts faster to price changes, while a longer period is smoother and less sensitive.
combined.oversoldThresholdHelp: RSI value below which to buy more (default: 30)
combined.oversoldThresholdTooltip: When RSI falls below this value, the strategy considers the asset oversold and increases the purchase amount. Lower values mean more conservative buying, higher values mean more aggressive buying.
combined.maPeriodTooltip: The number of days used to calculate the moving average. When price is below the moving average, it may indicate a buying opportunity.
combined.lookbackDaysHelp: Number of days to look back for recent high (default: 30)
combined.lookbackDaysTooltip: The number of days to look back to find the recent high price. A shorter period detects smaller dips, while a longer period only detects larger dips from longer-term highs.
combined.dropThresholdHelp: Percentage drop from recent high to trigger buy (default: 10%)
combined.dropThresholdTooltip: The percentage drop from the recent high price that triggers increased buying. Lower values trigger more often, higher values trigger less often.
combined.maxMultiplierHelp: Maximum multiplier when multiple signals align (default: 3.0x)
combined.maxMultiplierTooltip: The maximum purchase multiplier when multiple signals (RSI, Moving Average, and Dip) all align. This caps how aggressive the strategy can be even when all conditions are met. For example, 3.0x means buying at most 3 times the normal amount.

rebalancing.targetAllocationHelp: Target percentage of portfolio in assets (default: 80%)
rebalancing.targetAllocationTooltip: The target percentage of your portfolio that should be in assets. For example, 0.8 (80%) means you want 80% of your portfolio value in assets and 20% in USDC. The strategy will automatically buy or sell to maintain this allocation.
rebalancing.rebalanceThresholdHelp: Percentage drift from target before rebalancing (default: 10%)
rebalancing.rebalanceThresholdTooltip: How much the allocation can drift from the target before rebalancing is triggered. For example, with 80% target and 10% threshold, rebalancing occurs when allocation goes above 90% (sell assets) or below 70% (buy assets). Lower thresholds mean more frequent rebalancing. Set to 0 to disable threshold-based rebalancing.
rebalancing.rebalanceScheduleHelp: Rebalance on a schedule in addition to threshold-based rebalancing (default: none)
rebalancing.rebalanceScheduleTooltip: Rebalance on a regular schedule (weekly, monthly, quarterly, half-yearly, or yearly) in addition to threshold-based rebalancing. The strategy will rebalance when either the schedule is due OR the threshold is breached, whichever comes first. Set to 'none' to only use threshold-based rebalancing.

metadata.title: Strategy Comparison Results
metadata.investmentAmountTooltip: The total amount of money you allocated for this backtest.
metadata.dateRangeTooltip: The time period that was tested in this backtest.
metadata.timeframeTooltip: The granularity of market data used (1h = hourly, 4h = 4-hour, 1d = daily, 1w = weekly, 1m = monthly).
metadata.noResults: No results available. Please run a comparison first.

metrics.strategyTooltip: The name of the investment strategy being compared.
metrics.totalReturnTooltip: The total percentage gain or loss from your initial investment. For example, +100% means you doubled your money. This includes both coin value and any remaining cash.
metrics.finalValueTooltip: The total value of your portfolio at the end of the test period. This includes the value of all coins you own plus any remaining cash (USDC) that wasn't invested.
metrics.avgBuyPriceTooltip: The average price at which you purchased coins throughout the strategy. Lower is better - it means you bought at better prices on average.
metrics.maxDrawdownTooltip: The largest percentage drop from a peak value during the test period. For example, if your portfolio reached $10,000 and then dropped to $7,500, that's a 25% drawdown. Lower is better - it shows less risk.
metrics.totalInvestmentTooltip: The total amount of money you allocated for this strategy. This is the starting capital you set in the form.
metrics.totalQuantityTooltip: The total amount of cryptocurrency (e.g., BTC) you accumulated by the end of the test period.
metrics.sharpeRatioTooltip: A measure of risk-adjusted returns. Higher is better - it means you got better returns relative to the risk taken. A Sharpe ratio above 1 is considered good, above 2 is very good.
metrics.actionsTooltip: View detailed transaction history for this strategy.

transactions.title: Transactions
transactions.dateTooltip: The date when this transaction was made according to the strategy rules.
transactions.typeTooltip: Whether this is a buy transaction (purchasing BTC) or a sell transaction (selling BTC).
transactions.priceTooltip: The price of the cryptocurrency (e.g., BTC) at the time of transaction, in USD.
transactions.amountTooltip: The USD value of this transaction. For buys, this is money spent. For sells, this is money received.
transactions.quantityPurchasedTooltip: The amount of cryptocurrency (e.g., BTC) bought or sold in this transaction. Positive for buys, negative for sells. Calculated as: Amount รท Price.
transactions.remainingCoinTooltip: The total value (in USD) of all cryptocurrency you own after this transaction. This is calculated as: Total Quantity ร Current Price.
transactions.remainingUsdcTooltip: The amount of cash (USDC) you still have available after this transaction. Buys reduce this amount, sells increase it.
transactions.totalPortfolioValueTooltip: Your complete portfolio value after this transaction. This includes both the value of your coins and any remaining cash. Formula: Coin Value + Remaining USDC.
transactions.reasonTooltip: Why this transaction was made. For example, 'Weekly DCA purchase' means it was a scheduled regular purchase, 'RSI < 30' means the strategy detected oversold conditions, or 'Rebalancing: BTC allocation 90% > 90% threshold' means the portfolio was rebalanced.
